t: Nahum 3
Woe to Nineveh
Woe*pn to the city of blood, full*ld of lies, full*ln of plunder, never*ld without victims!
The*ln crack of whips, the*ld clatter of wheels, galloping*ln horses and*ld jolting chariots!
Charging*ln cavalry, flashing*ld swords and*ld glittering spears! Many*ln casualties, piles*ld of dead, bodies*ln without number, people*ld stumbling over the corpses—
all*ln because of the wanton lust of a prostitute, alluring,*ld the mistress of sorceries, who*ln enslaved nations by her prostitution and*ld peoples by her witchcraft.
“I*pn am against you,” declares the Lord*s Almighty. “I*ld will lift your skirts over your face. I*ln will show the nations your nakedness and*ld the kingdoms your shame.
I*ln will pelt you with filth, I*ld will treat you with contempt and*ld make you a spectacle.
All*ln who see you will flee from you and say, ‘Nineveh*ld is in ruins—who will mourn for her?’ Where*ld can I find anyone to comfort you?”
Are*pn you better than Thebes, situated*ld on the Nile, with*ld water around her? The*ln river was her defense, the*ld waters her wall.
Cush*ln and Egypt were her boundless strength; Put*ld and Libya were among her allies.
Yet*ln she was taken captive and*ld went into exile. Her*ln infants were dashed to pieces at*ld every street corner. Lots*ln were cast for her nobles, and*ld all her great men were put in chains.
You*ln too will become drunk; you*ld will go into hiding and*ld seek refuge from the enemy.
All*pn your fortresses are like fig trees with*ld their first ripe fruit; when*ln they are shaken, the*ld figs fall into the mouth of the eater.
Look*ln at your troops— they*ld are all weaklings. The*ln gates of your land are*ld wide open to your enemies; fire*ld has consumed the bars of your gates.
Draw*pn water for the siege, strengthen*ld your defenses! Work*ln the clay, tread*ld the mortar, repair*ld the brickwork!
There*ln the fire will consume you; the*ld sword will cut you down— they*ld will devour you like a swarm of locusts. Multiply*ln like grasshoppers, multiply*ld like locusts!
You*ln have increased the number of your merchants till*ld they are more numerous than the stars in the sky, but*ln like locusts they strip the land and*ld then fly away.
Your*ln guards are like locusts, your*ld officials like swarms of locusts that*ld settle in the walls on a cold day— but*ln when the sun appears they fly away, and*ld no one knows where.
King*pn of Assyria, your shepherds slumber; your*ld nobles lie down to rest. Your*ln people are scattered on the mountains with*ld no one to gather them.
Nothing*ln can heal you; your*ld wound is fatal. All*ln who hear the news about you clap*ld their hands at your fall, for*ln who has not felt your*ld endless cruelty?
